Away back in the early seventies, when this work Was fin&t intro- duced to tho business nam of the Northwest, there was little demand for it in the sparsely settled regions, but the publishers had an abid- mg faith in the future of this great Northwestern Empire, and they continued the publication, improving and developing it with the growth of the country, until now it lias become a standard • of reference and authority for everything that pertains I sota. North and South Dakota and Montana, for it represents every city, village and settlement and every individual and firm transact- ing business in each and every place. The Gazetteer has 1 dispensable to all classes of people, not only the merchant, tin- banker, the manufacture]' and the professional man in the cities, 1 to every inhabitant in the smaller villages in the four states those living and doing business in every hamlet and settlement. It is the only work of its kind in the Northwest. A wonderful change has taken place in this community since the first issue of the Gazetteer. Then there were only 590,0 the four states, now there are 4,200,000 citizens. The 5rs1 contained only 500 pages; the volume for ll)0b contains ^.'i'JS pages, which is an increase of 120 per emit. There Were about 7"<> v: and settlements in the first Gazetteer and there are nearly >.(■■ the present edition. There has been an increase of nearly 60 lages and settlements in the past two years. There is probably no other work that so clearly deraonstr I - wonderful growth that has taken place in these Northwestern s1 during- the past thirty years. No other portion of the North A can continent has grown to the same" extent, and it is quite e> that a new era of growth and prosperity has ensued and en r« mous as the growth has been in the past il will be infinitely g in the next few years. The Northwest is the most vigorous and prosperous section of the United States today. "The climate, the people, tho Datura] re- sources and advantages all combine to bring about Ibis pr< 5] condition. The Gazetteer has contributed iis share t-. this fav< state of affairs for there is nothing more conducive to tie . ment and expansion of trade and commerce thau an easy means Cli communication such as is afforded by a reliable work of which clearly sets forth the conditions existing in ever} nook and corner of this t rade center. In the early nineties the cities had outgrown the rural districts and had attained a population greater than could he supported by the rural districts. The presenl issue of the Gazetteer shows that the greatest urowth has been in the rural districts, wh 1 lation has largely outgrown the cities, and there i^ now the i *1 favorable opportunity r<e,' prowth nnd prosperity in the large cities. which will wj\v share the success that has existed generally throughout every nook and corner of Minnesota, Dakota and Mon- tana. The Gazetteer lias become a standard work of reference, a use- ful and necessary compendium of business interests. It is the most widely circulated and -enoi-aily used work uf reference in the Xortl - west. It is the most economical and effective method for reaclr ._ the four millions of people, who live in this locality. It is a train- able buyer's guide, for here one may see at a glance the name of every house in any particular line of trade. A study of its well arranged and convenient classifications and the names of the bus - ness houses is like a visit to the market place. There are live departments to the Gazetteer. The first department is the alphabetical arrangrment of Minne- sota cities, villages ami settlements, pages 155 to 155'.). The second department is the alphabetical arrangement of North Dakota cities, villages and settlements, pages 1560 to 10S8. The third department is an alphabetical arrangement of South Dakota cities, villages and settlements, pages 1989 to 2350. The fourth department is an alphabetical arrangement of Mon- tana cities, villages and settlements, pages 2351 to 2619.
